I created a thread elsewhere in this forum hoping that someone else would help me texture some parts, but nobody has stepped up to help. So I revisited the UV mapping process in Blender to try to see what was going wrong. There\'s a frustrating problem that I don\'t know how to fix... When I used UV unwrapping on the model I\'m working on, I get a large web of unscaled triangles, rather than flattened surfaces. I\'ve defined four surfaces on my model, which is roughly cylindrical in shape, and only the flat top and bottom export to a flat plane, whereas the other two are exploded into individual triangles, making texturing pretty much impossible. I know that when others do the same thing, the editor automatically adjusts the surfaces to get a flat plane, so I\'m not sure what settings I need to change to make this work. Here are some screenshots of the problem:

Here\'s how the UV unwrap works:

http://dl.dropbox.com/u/43321825/problem%202.png

...which results in a problem that looks like this:

http://dl.dropbox.com/u/43321825/problem%201.png

For the curved part of any cylinder-type object, try Unwrap--> Cylinder Projection

Then before doing anything else, on the left side just below the Mesh-edit menus will be an 'unwrap properties' box. Click the Direction dropdown box, and change view on equator to 'Align on object'

At this point it should roughly fit in the square, and when you hit G to move it, it should scale and snap to fit (as long as you have Constrain to Image bound' checked in the 'UVs' menu.

Btw, since you arent doing animation to need the timeline, you can move the UV mapping pane down to the bottom area and leave Object/Area mode in the main pane. Then you can resize the lower pane when you need to work down there. (If you don\'t know, the icon on the left side of each menu bar lets you swap modes)

http://dl.dropbox.com/u/43321825/problem%203.png

That seems to have worked properly, but I\'m not sure how to add the UV for the top and bottom of the object to the one I currently have.

That seems to have worked properly, but I\'m not sure how to add the UV for the top and bottom of the object to the one I currently have.
You may unwrap them part-by-part. Select cylindrical wall and unwrap with Cylinder Projection; then select faces forming the cap and unwrap them in \'default\' mode (press <E> while mouse cursor is over UV window). Then move and resize each UV island as you wish.

Hint: to select all the UVs belonging to the same island click one of them, then <Ctrl-L> (\'select linked\').

Aha! Ok, so I have all of the parts of the UV laid out and ready, but now I\'d like to know how to make sure the exported image encompasses all of the islands. Currently, only the body is in bounds, while the top and bottom are out.

Ok, that was working for me, but then I accidentally hit file-new when I meant to move the window, which is something I\'ve done before and am tired of doing on accident. I repeated all of the steps, and now I have all the islands. Problem is, now I can\'t select the islands. Hitting Ctr.+L now only selects individual faces, and attempting to move them rips them out of the island. I also can\'t do a circular select with Ctr.+LMouse in the UV editor, which means I have no idea how to move the islands now.

Ok, never mind about the previous issue. I was able to work around it by selecting surfaces on the model and moving and resizing the islands individually. I exported the UV to an image and added texture, then placed the texture image into the editor. The image, which features tiles for the exterior of the spacecraft, was extremely distorted. Is this an issue with the texture, or the UV map?

Hitting Ctr.+L now only selects individual faces, and attempting to move them rips them out of the island. I also can\'t do a circular select with Ctr.+LMouse in the UV editor

UV editor seems to think your faces are not connected to each other; I dunno why.

Anyhow you can always press <B> for border select.

The image, which features tiles for the exterior of the spacecraft, was extremely distorted. Is this an issue with the texture, or the UV map?
Try to move individual vertices in UV map, and look will that distortion change?

More useful buttons: <W> invokes Weld menu allowing to weld all the selected vertices together, or align them along X or Y axes. It may help a lot to fix that UV distortion...

I\'m having a similar problem with the unwrapping. I\'m using the cylender unwrapping, but even when i hit 'align to object', it still comes out as slightly skewed.

Like this:

I can kludgily work around it by aligning my camera exactly horizontal, then unwrapping along the equator, but that\'s really kludgy and it still doesn\'t come out perfectly straight.

What\'s going on here?

go to the UV menu and uncheck 'Confine to image' and see if it expands, it seems like what you are unwrapping is overly large and getting crammed in.

Once its unwrapped, you can still scale it down using the S key ( and even: S, then X to scale only on X, S then Y to scale only on Y axis)

tried that. selecting 'scale to image' in the unwrap menu scaled it to the image bounds. Still comes out all funny shaped.

I found (from other tutorials) that hitting ctrl-A in Object mode and 'applying rotation', 'location' and 'scale' (whatever the hell that means) seems to help partially, but i still don\'t get the results I see in the stickied tutorial. The faces are aligned square now, but they\'re not all of the same size. The scaling is warped along the x-axis, which will make the texture come out warped.

Any idea what I\'m doing wrong? This seems like the simplest thing ever, and I just can\'t figure out what\'s happening.

Any idea what I\'m doing wrong? This seems like the simplest thing ever, and I just can\'t figure out what\'s happening.
I got similar results when unwrapping Jupiter model. The best thing I managed do was to select UV vertices column by column and space them evenly along X (<B> to border select, <G> then <X> to move along X only)...

I wonder is there an easier way?

hitting ctrl-A in Object mode and 'applying rotation', 'location' and 'scale' (whatever the hell that means) seems to help partially
When you move/rotate/scale an object Blender does not recalculate each vertex\' coordinate, it assigns a number to entire object instead (\'object is rotated to...\', \'scaled to...\' etc..). There are those numbers you see in Transform panel (<N> key in 3d view). When you \'Apply\' each vertex\' coordinates are recalculated and transform values are reset to 0.

I have never had a simple cylinder unwrap in a weird way like that. I am at a loss.

If you want to share a .blend file, perhaps we can poke around it and see if anything seems off.

I did figure out how to manually assign seams and unwrap it that way. That seems like it will work fine, for my purposes.

if you want to do some poking around, here\'s the blend file.
The remedy to your worries gabyalufix!
